page.title: 09LILLESHALL ABBEY
page.content: Lilleshall Abbey was built in 1150 after a Charter issued by King Stephen in 1148 mentioned an endowment of Richard de Belmeis to build an abbey. The Abbey was frequently used by passing travellers who were invited in to take part in the services and have free hospitality. During the reign of King Henry V111 the Abbey was closed down (1538). Later the King granted the Abbey to Sir William Cavendish who dismantled part of it. In 1539 the Abbey was sold to James Leveson of Wolverhampton. During the Civil War Sir Richard Leveson unsuccessfully tried to garrison the building against the Parliamentarians. By 1757 the Abbey had fallen into the state it is in now. Between the 2 World Wars a miniature railway used to run from the Abbey to Lilleshall Hall. The Ministry of Works took over in the early 1950's
